Situation1: Their family members have recently emphasized the importance of maintaining long-held customs.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my mother’s voice echoing in my mind about the importance of our family traditions. Just last night, she reminded me how proud she was that I always respected our customs, especially now that the family was paying closer attention. I could almost feel the weight of their expectations pressing on my shoulders. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder from my mentor: “Don’t hesitate to reach out if you have any questions, no matter how small.” I did have a question—just a minor confusion about a term in my project. It wasn’t urgent, but my mentor had always stressed the importance of open communication. Yet, I hesitated. In my family, we’re taught not to bother others with trivial matters, to handle small things ourselves. I stared at my phone, torn between honoring my family’s values and meeting my mentor’s expectations. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, my heart pounding as I wrestled with which role to honor in this moment.
